tvShows.teaserText: Insight investigates and analyses topical issues that impact Asia and the rest of the world.

teaserVideo.caption: Two young Hong Kongers, a pro-democracy activist and a pro-Beijing YouTuber, meet for the first time in a candid discussion on Hong Kong�s political situation. Can the youths on opposite political spectrum find any common ground?
teaserVideo.title: Insight 2020/2021 - S1: Hong Kong's Divided Gen Z: Can pro-democracy & pro-Beijing youths talk without fighting?

tvShows.description: Insight investigates and analyses topical issues that impact Asia and the rest of the world.
tvShows.title: Insight 2020/2021

tvShows.teaserText: Insight investigates and analyses topical issues that impact Asia and the rest of the world.

teaserVideo.caption:
As part of its quest for carbon neutrality by 2060, China is planning to build the world�s biggest dam for a hydropower project on the Yarlung Tsango, or the Brahmaputra as it�s known in India. The river flows through Tibet, China, Bangladesh and India,.

But there are grave worries about the mega dam�s detrimental environmental impact, and how it might affect the downstream communities. The story of the Mekong river presents a cautionary precedent.
teaserVideo.title: Insight 2021/2022 - S1E31: People of the Mekong fight for survival, in the shadow of China�s mega dams

tvShows.description: Insight investigates and analyses topical issues that impact Asia and the rest of the world.
tvShows.title: Insight 2021/2022

tvShows.teaserText:
When disaster strikes in Asia, Singapore General Hospital is ready at a moment's notice. Driven by emotional first-hand testimony, the series tells the story of Asia's most catastrophic disasters from the perspective of the doctors, who went beyond the call of duty to save lives.

Episode One provides an up-close look inside the SGH burns unit. Doctors, nurses and skin transplant specialists used creative, cutting-edge techniques to treat a young Singaporean girl, who suffered 80% burns in one of Taiwan's worst ever fires caused by combustible powders.

Episode Two takes us to Nepal, where a team of specially selected emergency doctors from SGH and the Singapore Armed Forces were rushed out to Kathmandu after a massive 7.8 magnitude earthquake left thousands dead in 2015.

With gripping reconstructions and original archives, this series takes you to the heart of the action, whether it is the operating theatre or a makeshift medical tent in the epicentre of a disaster zone.

teaserVideo.caption: A team of specially selected emergency doctors and nurses from Singapore General Hospital are rushed out to Nepal after a massive 7.8 magnitude earthquake left thousands dead in 2015.
teaserVideo.title: Into The Unknown: Doctors On Call - S1E2: Nepal Earthquake

tvShows.description: When disaster strikes in Asia, Singapore is the first port of call. These are the stories of Singapore General Hospital doctors, who have gone beyond the call of duty to save lives overseas.
tvShows.title: Into The Unknown: Doctors On Call

tvShows.teaserText:
A missing photo album of a special flight from the 1970s. A long-buried secret underneath Singapore�s �Gotham City�. A curious murder from 1934 that is more than it seems. And a legendary white crocodile that is rumoured to roam the Kallang River, but never photographed.

Four Singaporeans go on four new missions to find answers to mysteries from the past, and uncover more unusual, surprising, even frightening chapters from Singapore�s history. From the island�s bloody episode as a gang-ridden �Chicago of the East� in the 1920s, to the great romance of air travel during the golden age of aviation in the 1970s, what else lies forgotten in the vault of time?

teaserVideo.caption: Podcast producer Rovik Robert investigates a mysterious murder of a British policeman in 1934, and discovers Singapore�s gruesome past when guns and gangs reigned.
teaserVideo.title: Into The Vault - S3E4: Sin City Singapore

tvShows.description: A lost village in �Gotham City�, a legendary white crocodile, a missing flight, and a curious murder from 1934 � four Singaporeans uncover four more mysteries in this new season of Into the Vault.
tvShows.title: Into The Vault

tvShows.teaserText: A million wildlife species are facing the threat of extinction. But why does this matter to a tiny city state like Singapore? What do we stand to lose if our wildlife go extinct? Host Lam Shushan comes face to face with some of the rarest creatures in the world and meets the tenacious frontliners who are racing to save our native wildlife from extinction.

teaserVideo.caption: As we clear more forests to make way for urban development, what can we do to make sure we don't lose more of our wildlife? Is it already too late, and can a tiny city state like Singapore play a part in preserving the planet's biodiversity? We follow the men and women in the frontline of our fight to save our wildlife.
teaserVideo.title: It's In Our Nature - S1E2: Saving Our Wildlife

tvShows.description: A million wildlife species are facing the threat of extinction. But why does this matter to a tiny city state like Singapore? What do we stand to lose if our wildlife go extinct?
tvShows.title: It's In Our Nature

tvShows.teaserText:
Winter in Japan (Dec - Feb)
The days may be short and the nights much longer, but this is the season when Japan is at its most captivating with its' streets lit up with spectacular glowing lights.

teaserVideo.caption: A look at the people, places, culture and food of Japan for everyone to experience and enjoy.
teaserVideo.title: Japan Hour - S4E1: Road Trip On Kominato Tetsudo - Part 1

tvShows.description: Your insider guide to Japan. Get a taste of Japanese travel, food and culture on Japan Hour!
tvShows.title: Japan Hour

tvShows.teaserText:
25 years ago, Japan controlled 50% of the global video game market. Today, it is under 10%. What is the cause of this decline? And what is Japan�s future in this $135 billion US dollar industry?

Throughout the 80�s and 90�s Japan was a dominant force in video games, with mega hits in the gaming arcades such as Pac Man, and then they dominated the console market with Nintendo and Sega who brought the world games such as Mario and Sonic. By 1995, Japan controlled 80% of the global console market.

However, close regional competiton started to emerge. And they soon began to have a massive impact on the way the world played video games. Communal game playing in Korea�s so called �PC Bangs� in the late 90�s also gave birth to eSports, and in China, mobile gaming exploded over the last ten years.

But Japan is not taking things lying down. With new developments in the past few years like Nintendo Switch and gaming favourites like Animal Crossing, Japan looks set to make a comeback.

teaserVideo.caption: 25 years ago, Japan controlled 50% of the global video game market. Today, it is under 10%. We explore the rise and fall of Japan�s gaming industry and how it�s gaining steam again in recent years.
teaserVideo.title: Japan�s Comeback Game: Can Japan's Gaming Industry Make A Return?

tvShows.description: 25 years ago, Japan controlled 50% of the global video game market. Today, it is under 10%. We explore the rise and fall of Japan�s gaming industry and how it�s gaining steam again in recent years.
tvShows.title: Japan�s Comeback Game

tvShows.teaserText:
Jewel Changi Airport is the latest, well, jewel in Singapore�s tourism crown. The sprawling 135,700 sqm complex, with its heady mix of nature and architecture, retail and restaurants, has garnered considerable accolades from local fans and international press alike.

Behind the beautiful flora and majestic waterfall and under its gleaming facade, who keeps Jewel polished? Filmed mostly at night, Jewel After Hours takes a peek behind Changi�s newest gem.

We will tell the story of the people who work behind-the-scenes, often into the wee hours, to maintain Singapore's latest icon. Through their stories, we will reveal what the island nation has in store for travellers in the coming years.

teaserVideo.caption: Take a look at a different facet of Singapore's latest gem, Jewel Changi Airport. Who are the people working behind-the-scenes, often into the wee hours of the morning, keeping Jewel polished?
teaserVideo.title: Jewel: After Hours: What Does It Take To Maintain Singapore's Jewel Changi Airport?

tvShows.description: Take a look at a different facet of Singapore�s latest gem, Jewel Changi Airport. Who are the people working behind-the-scenes, often into the wee hours of the morning, keeping Jewel polished?
tvShows.title: Jewel: After Hours

tvShows.teaserText: A docu-series that follows the journey of six individuals with mental and physical disabilities, who are striving to achieve a particular goal. The show hopes to change perspectives that people with disabilities are no different, and they can accomplish great things if given the same opportunities as everyone else.

teaserVideo.caption: Timothy relies on his helper for his daily needs, and needs help to move around as he's unable to straighten his limbs, much less walk. Despite his weakening muscles and lungs, he enjoys singing immensely. He dreams of recording his own song with the help of popular music duo, Jack & Rai.
teaserVideo.title: Just Like You - S1E6: Timothy - The Surprising Singer

tvShows.description: A docu-series that follows the journey of six individuals with mental and physical disabilities, who are striving to achieve a particular goal. The show hopes to change perspectives that people with disabilities are no different, and they can accomplish great things if given the same opportunities as everyone else.

tvShows.teaserText:
When Singapore shuts down, six everyday heroes step up to help their neighbours during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. From nationwide quarantine to national celebration, they uplift communities with compassion and resilience, proving that the kampong spirit shines brightest in dark times.

Mae Tan recovered from COVID-19 and started an online initiative to connect vulnerable residents with volunteer befrienders. Kee Sek Soon, a businessman and grassroots leader, installed over 200 hand sanitisers throughout Fengshan. Tan Chee Wee, a schoolteacher and volunteer policeman, sacrificed his holidays to keep communities safe. Nizar Mohd Shariff and his charity distributed food to thousands of migrant workers and needy residents. Rahimah Rahim volunteered to ration food to her neighbours from the community fridge under her block. U. K. Shyam, a former athlete and teacher, volunteered to help students level up by distributing refurbished laptops to students in need

teaserVideo.caption: They are single mums staying in public rental flats - who dip into their own pockets to make sure their neighbours don�t go hungry, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic.
teaserVideo.title: Kampong Konkrit - S1: Single mums help feed hungry neighbours in need

tvShows.description: When Singapore shuts down, six everyday heroes step up to help their neighbours during a nationwide quarantine, uplifting community and kampong spirit amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
tvShows.title: Kampong Konkrit

tvShows.teaserText: A confronting one-hour documentary special that goes inside the minds of Kashmiri youth fighting a bitter struggle for independence. The film investigates why militancy is intensifying amongst the youth and why young rebel recruits are now more alienated than ever.The disputed territory is a place where rebel ambushes of the 700,000 Indian troops are a regular occurrence and where youth confront troops often with nothing more than stones as a weapon. The Indian armed forces are determined to defend their territory against the insurgents but it�s coming at a huge cost in human lives. The reality of life under Indian occupation in the Kashmir Valley is told through a number of key characters. Expert historians, human rights activists, and Government officials place the historical and geo-political context of the struggle as we come to understand the brutal experience that is life in the Kashmiri Valley, and why, despite the dangers, youth militancy is on the rise.

teaserVideo.caption: In the conflict-ridden Kashmir valley, killings in encounters never stop. 60% of the Valley�s population is below the age of 30. With human rights abuses by the armed forces, more and more youth,attracted to miltancy, are prepared to risk their lives.
teaserVideo.title: Kashmir: A War of Stones - S1E1: Kashmir: A War Of Stones

tvShows.description: In the conflict-ridden Kashmir valley, killings in encounters never stop. 60% of the Valley�s population is below the age of 30. With human rights abuses by armed forces, more youth are attracted to miltancy and are prepared to risk their lives.
tvShows.title: Kashmir: A War of Stones

tvShows.teaserText:
What will Singapore be like in the future, as city planners, corporations and scientists find new ways to overcome land shortage? The ground under our feet, the sea around the island, even empty spaces above roads and canals might be used for transportation, storage, homes, offices and other infrastructure.

The series showcases how other land-scarce cities Tokyo, Hong Kong, London and Helsinki use these unusual locations to overcome limited land, and what Singapore can learn from their experiences.

teaserVideo.caption: Service depots are important to keep Singapore�s trains and buses running efficiently. In land-scarce Singapore, we�ve found a way to optimize space and create a world first.
teaserVideo.title: Land Unlimited - S1: World's First Mega Depot

tvShows.description: Singapore transforms its underground spaces, water bodies and more to create new opportunities despite its land constraints.
tvShows.title: Land Unlimited

tvShows.teaserText: From instilling order to fighting for women's rights and eradicating corruption, key laws have been essential in shaping the character of Singapore society. Witness how social and political pressures influenced major legislative changes as dramatic re-enactments bring pivotal historical events alive.

teaserVideo.caption: From instilling order to fighting for women's rights and eradicating corruption, key laws have been essential in shaping the character of Singapore society. Witness how social and political pressures influenced major legislative changes as dramatic re-enactments bring pivotal historical events alive.

tvShows.teaserText: A factual documentary series showcasing Singapore's pioneering and groundbreaking surgical and medical procedures and developments. Told through the eyes of everyday Singaporeans facing life changing and life threatening conditions, and the doctors who strive to help them.

teaserVideo.caption: Doctors at NUH use groundbreaking brain mapping techniques to remove a tumour from Rajendran's brain, while the SGH medical team must remove Mr Chan's parathyroid glands from his neck to treat his crippling bone pain. And have experts at SNEC discovered the answer to Asia's Cornea Donor shortage?
teaserVideo.title: Life Lines - S1: Episode 3

tvShows.description: A factual documentary series showcasing Singapore's pioneering and groundbreaking surgical and medical procedures and developments.
tvShows.title: Life Lines

tvShows.teaserText:
This series explores history through the lens of personal romances - the tragic and revolutionary, the loyal and long-lasting, and the passionate and divisive. Three true tales of the heart give us new insights into Singapore�s past and the way its attitudes to love and marriage transformed over the course of the 20th century. Milestones in Singapore history are approached through the intimate impact on personal lives. Today, we take for granted the idea of love and love matches, yet things were not always so open, attitudes not always so progressive, and romance not always so easy.

Each episode focuses on a couple whose relationship crossed boundaries and changed history. These stories are told through a seamless mixture of dramatic re-enactment, period footage and images, and expert interviews to help us approach history through a very different lens.

teaserVideo.caption: In 1950s Singapore, the British were no longer welcome, and the great divorce was on the horizon. The relationship of author Han Suyin and British colonial police officer Leon Comber captured the conflict of the Malayan Emergency as Singapore moved towards independence.
teaserVideo.title: Love in A Time of Change - S1E3: Till Politics Do Us Part: Han Suyin & Leon Comber

tvShows.description: Three real life romance give us new insights into Singapore�s past, and the way its attitudes to love and marriage transformed over the course of the 20th century. Each episode focuses on a couple whose relationship crossed boundaries and changed history.
tvShows.title: Love In A Time Of Change

tvShows.teaserText: Singapore is not lacking in inventors and inventions. And yet, many of our original creations have stayed under the radar and users have not been aware of their home-grown origins. From milk bottles to a drinks machine, hi-tech thermal sensors to low-tech kitchenware, and gadgets for niche pastime. Who are the people behind these innovations? What are their inspirations and what drives them to create? This new 4-part series tells the stories behind 8 sets of inventors and their inventions.

teaserVideo.caption: They once laughed at his dream to become a full time stand-up comedian. Today, Fuzz�s brother and best friend share the satisfaction of calling him one of the funniest people in Singapore.
teaserVideo.title: Made in Singapore - S1: #DIAL of Fakkah Fuzz

tvShows.description: From milk bottles to drinks machine, hi-tech thermal sensors to low-tech kitchen ware, and gagdets for niche pastimes. Who are the people behind these creations? What inspired them?  Here are the stories behind these inventors and their inventions.
tvShows.title: Made In Singapore

tvShows.teaserText: On 3rd December 1959, Singapore unveiled its new state symbols the flag, crest and its first native head of state. These symbols embodies the nation�s highest ideals. But behind them remain stories unknown to many Singaporeans. We find out the inspirations and their relevance to Singaporeans 60 years on.

teaserVideo.caption: On 3rd December 1959, Singapore unveiled its new state symbols: the flag, crest and its first native head of state. Discover intriguing stories behind Singapore's state symbols.
teaserVideo.title: Majulah: Symbols For Singapore: The Story Of Singapore's State Symbols

tvShows.description: On 3rd December 1959, Singapore unveiled its new state symbols: the flag, crest and its first native head of state. Discover intriguing stories behind Singapore�s state symbols.
tvShows.title: Majulah: Symbols For Singapore

tvShows.teaserText:
CNA tracks three individuals in Hong Kong, Bangkok and Singapore, as the global jobs crisis wreaks havoc in their lives amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

In Hong Kong, Alba loses her job as an air stewardess, forcing her to eke out a living making food deliveries. She hustles to find other options, while holding on to her dream of becoming a pilot.

In Bangkok, as borders close, and clients dry up, Air is sacked from her job as a business development director. She scrambles to set up a business selling chilli paste. But as she struggles to stay afloat, she keeps a brave face to stop her aged parents from worrying.

In Singapore, retrenchment forces Daryll to enter a new sector despite a steep pay cut. With a newborn and a condo to pay for, Daryll takes on part-time work. But the long hours take a toll on his body and force him to miss the key moments in his son�s life.

Witness up close how a pandemic and the measures to fight it, touch the lives of ordinary people in three Asian cities.

teaserVideo.caption: What does being a food delivery rider in Singapore and in Hong Kong have in common? Long hours, tough weather, bad luck. The stories of two retrenched PMETs who did what it took to get by.
teaserVideo.title: Make It Work - S1E1: Surviving as a food delivery rider in Singapore & Hong Kong

tvShows.description: Peek into the lives of three individuals in three Asian cities, as the global jobs crisis triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic gets personal.
tvShows.title: Make It Work

Experts from around the world discuss trends that are driving the global economic rebound, growth and value opportunities, along with the factors affecting ESG investments.

Brought to you by UOB

teaserVideo.caption:
As the rollout of COVID-19 vaccinations continues, the reopening of the global economy appears well underway. However, markets remain volatile.

An expert panel from Singapore, America and Europe discuss the opportunities that could arise amid the risks of a delayed recovery.

Rising inflation concerns, tax implications, interest hikes, growth and value options along with Environmental, Social and Governance investment opportunities were covered during the virtual event. 

Get key insights on their market outlook for the rest of 2021.
teaserVideo.title: Market Insights - S1: A World In Transition

tvShows.teaserText: The night is half of our lives. But how much do we really know about it, and its impact on us here in Singapore? Midnight Story seeks to unlock NASA�s little known but ground-breaking Black Marble project that is able to capture high resolution imagery from Space to paint a completely new picture of the Earth at night. Through unprecedented exclusive access to the NASA Black Marble project � we will turn our attention to nocturnal scientists, researchers and creatives in Singapore to document what their specialist insights and technology can reveal about the city state when the sun sets. The signal that can be seen at night is predominantly a human one � as we watch the light push into the darkness. Nowhere is this clearer than in the Lion City with our highly urbanized society. But what can this novel technology and innovative science teach us about Singapore?

teaserVideo.caption: Through unprecedented access to NASA�s Black Marble satellite imagery, Midnight Story delves into the endeavors of nocturnal scientists, naturalists and creatives after the sun sets in Singapore.
teaserVideo.title: Midnight Story: Singapore After Dark

tvShows.description: Through unprecedented access to NASA�s Black Marble satellite imagery, Midnight Story delves into the endeavors of nocturnal scientists, naturalists and creatives after the sun sets in Singapore.
tvShows.title: Midnight Story

tvShows.teaserText:
In �Migrants� Diary�, migrant worker diary entries and poems entwine the stories of two tenacious migrant workers who persevered to succeed in Singapore.

Sarowar is a safety supervisor from Bangladesh who has a passion for construction site safety because he once witnessed a fellow worker fall off a tall ladder and get seriously injured. Raj is a dormitory supervisor from India whose empathy with migrant workers stems from having been taken advantage of by his first employer in Singapore. Both of them rose up to leadership positions through determination, merit and good fortune. Now they volunteer their time to assist fellow migrant workers.

A foreign labourer�s experience in Singapore is challenging. Their struggles with homesickness, heartache and fatigue are encapsulated in the poetry of Bangladeshi migrant worker Md Sharif Uddin. Observational and poetic, the documentary is a window into a seldom heard and little understood segment of Singapore society.

teaserVideo.caption: �One time, I saw a worker die. For a few days and nights, I couldn't sleep properly." Meet the folks making sure Singapore�s migrant workers, who face risks every day, return home safe and whole to their families.
teaserVideo.title: Migrants' Diary - S1: Keeping Singapore�s migrant workers safe

tvShows.description: Migrant worker diary entries and poems entwine the stories of two tenacious migrant workers who persevered to succeed in Singapore.
tvShows.title: Migrants' Diary

What happens when you find your fridge packed with lots of leftover or untouched food which is still good for consumption? Joakim Gomez challenges two self-confessed food hoarders to repurpose food from their respective fridges and all it takes is a little planning and creativity.

Read more about the issue of food waste and what we can all do about it.

tvShows.teaserText: 2017 marks the 50th year of national service in Singapore. To commemorate this journey of service, Channel NewsAsia presents a two-part special to tell the story of how a fledgling nation built a citizen�s army from scratch, and its evolution into a modern-day institution powered by cutting-edge technology. Through personal stories of the pioneers and dramatic reconstructions, NATIONAL SERVICE: THE BEGINNING shows the first batch from the day they received their enlistment letters, to the notorious training methods and food, and the historic National Day parade in 1968 - where they stood before a grateful nation. In NATIONAL SERVICE: THE TRANSFORMATION, we fast-forward to 2017 Singapore. We delve into the evolution of national service and understand how we are making the switch from jungle to urban warfare. Through it all, we come to see national service as a shared experience that has bound hundreds of thousands of Singaporean men over five decades.

teaserVideo.caption: 17th August 1967 - 900 Singaporean men were called upon to take an oath that marked a milestone in Singapore history. This documentary calls on the first batch of national servicemen who share their stories through interviews and dramatic reconstructions.
teaserVideo.title: National Service - The Beginning - S1: National Service: The Beginning

tvShows.description: A two-part special to tell the story of a fledgling nation building a citizen�s army from scratch, and its evolution into a modern-day institution powered by cutting-edge technology.
tvShows.title: National Service - The Beginning

tvShows.teaserText: Singapore and Malaysia are geographically divided by the Johor Strait. But they are closely linked in many ways, with shared history, shared culture and shared heritage. And as in all close relationships, there are differences, some of them long standing. This programme will look at differences that have resurfaced recently over the price of water, airspace control and port limits, providing an overview and explanation of the issues. It will examine implications and what�s at stake as the neighbours sit down to resolve these issues and whether there are outcomes that will benefit both sides.

teaserVideo.caption: Singapore and Malaysia are closely linked, but with their share of ups and downs. How will they resolve their latest differences and are there outcomes that benefit both sides?
teaserVideo.title: Neighbours: Singapore-Malaysia Relations: -

tvShows.description: Singapore and Malaysia are closely linked, but with their share of ups and downs. How will they resolve their latest differences and are there outcomes that benefit both sides?

tvShows.teaserText: Home to 28 million people, Nepal masks a centuries old practice. The country registers one of the highest child marriages in the world with 37% of girls married under the legal age of 20 years. Steeped in patriarchy and poverty, women are viewed as a burden to be unloaded through marriage as early as possible. This widespread practice often leads to girls dropping out of school, life-threatening teenage pregnancies, sexual abuse at the hands of their husbands to even dowry-related murders. In a Channel NewsAsia investigation, we visit remote villages in the Himalayan country to follow activists fighting an uphill battle against centuries old traditions and customs with an aim to create awareness to stop child marriages.

teaserVideo.caption: Nearly 37% of girls married in Nepal are under the legal age of 20 years. We investigate why patriarchal traditions are leading to child marriages, rising teenage pregnancies to even dowry related murders and meet the activists fighting against it.
teaserVideo.title: Nepal's Child Brides - S1: Nepal's Child Brides

tvShows.description: Nearly 37% of girls married in Nepal are under the legal age of 20 years. We investigate why patriarchal traditions are leading to child marriages, rising teenage pregnancies to even dowry related murders and meet the activists fighting against it.
tvShows.title: Nepal's Child Brides

tvShows.teaserText:
As Singapore battled the COVID-19 pandemic, many residents joined the fight in many different capacities. Any success in the nation's response to the crisis is due in no small part to all the individuals who stepped up and contributed, often going above and beyond the call of duty. Among these were new citizens and permanent residents. From volunteering in a migrant workers dormitory to ensuring the safety in a mall, these people may have had roots elsewhere but have firmly planted them in Singapore now. We learn what made them choose this country and how they have made it a home they love and want to protect.

Brought to you by Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI), Singapore

teaserVideo.caption: Having chosen to call Singapore home, Manful Chan was more than ready to step up and be counted in the battle against COVID-19. As a hospital radiographer, his work was cut out for him and his team. But they still went the extra mile...
teaserVideo.title: On Common Ground - S1E4: Manful�s Story

tvShows.description: As Singapore battled COVID-19, many individuals stepped up and contributed to the fight. Among these were new citizens and permanent residents. We learn how they have made this place a home they love and want to protect.
tvShows.title: On Common Ground

teaserVideo.caption: Host Ching Shu Yi ventures into the dark spaces of the cyber underground and finds herself hacked, stalked and spied on by almost any device around her, from hidden drones to her own mobile phone.

tvShows.teaserText:
In this series, we visit 4 extraordinary people with a shared link - they were once refugees.

Conflicts and persecution within Asia made them refugees, but their personal journeys are as varied as the homelands they left behind. Today, each has overcome adversity to find meaning and success in different forms.

Zarny Shibuya arrived in Tokyo from Myanmar when he was 8. He is now an established fashion designer with his own label.

Ronel Chakma Nani escaped persecution in Bangladesh�s Chittagong Hill Tracts, and now fights for human rights from South Korea.

Vietnamese Farah Dang was born in a refugee camp in Hong Kong. Now she is a dedicated volunteer helping refugees still awaiting repatriation.

Svay Sareth is a Cambodian artist who uses art to make sense of the 13 years spent in a refugee camp on the Thai-Cambodia border.

We see the lives they have built and explore the lasting influence their refugee experience has had on their outlook and identity.

teaserVideo.caption: To escape the violence of the Khmer Rouge, Cambodian Svay Sareth spent 13 years living in a refugee camp on the Thai-Cambodia border. Today, working from Siem Reap, he is an award-winning contemporary artist who channels the struggles of his past into his art.
teaserVideo.title: Once a Refugee - S1E4: Healing Through Art

tvShows.description: In Japan, Korea, Hong Kong and Cambodia, we meet 4 extraordinary people with a shared link - they were all once refugees. All of them have overcome adversity to find meaning and success, and today, their refugee experience is all the more illuminating for the rest of us.
tvShows.title: Once a Refugee

tvShows.teaserText: In this three-part series, we discover historical ties between communities and with some of the most critical waterways in Asia. On this journey, we discover how rivers have influenced people's way of life and how their fate and fortunes are dependant on water.

teaserVideo.caption: We investigate why Cambodia's new hydropower dams on the Mekong River are leaving fishing and farming communities high and dry. Will climate change going to make matters worse?
teaserVideo.title: Once Upon A River - S1E3: Trouble On The Mekong

tvShows.description: A three part series that investigates the impact of dwindling freshwater resources across Asia.
tvShows.title: Once Upon A River

tvShows.teaserText:
In just one day, a whole world can be transformed. An act of terror can bring neighbours to the edge of war; a religious movement can attempt to poison thousands on a subway; a natural disaster can contaminate the soil, earth and air for generations; and traditional religious rivalry can suddenly burst into violence and change the future of a country.

In this series, we look at how the two Koreas� game of brinkmanship in the 1980s resulted in a plane crash that reverberates to this day. In Japan, some 10 years after a nuclear reactor goes into meltdown, the government is trying to do the unprecedented - repopulate whole towns in Fukushima.

A terrifying poison gas attack on the Tokyo subway system exposes years of official failure to prevent a new religion mutating into a murderous cult.

And in Indonesia, an unprecedented natural disaster all but destroys a society but also triggers an end to a bitter civil war.

teaserVideo.caption: Tokyo, March 20, 1995. Subway commuters begin to choke and collapse. They've been poisoned with sarin gas. Disciples of an obscure New Religion have decided they need to kill all of humanity to save mankind. How did this happen and why?
teaserVideo.title: One Day That Changed Asia - S1E5: Tokyo�s Sarin Scars

tvShows.description: In just one day, whole worlds can change. Lives can be lost or saved, futures ruined or restored. This series features stories of mortal danger, terror and loss, redemption and hope, that happened over One Day that Changed Asia.
tvShows.title: One Day That Changed Asia

tvShows.teaserText: At the height of the COVID-19 outbreak in Singapore, Singapore�s foreign workers are urgently relocated to new and safer housing in a bid to mitigate infection spread. An intimate account from workers, volunteers and officers from various agencies involved, in an operation that is unprecedented in magnitude.

teaserVideo.caption: Producer Pearl Forss shares about the safety precautions she took documenting the massive effort to contain the virus� spread among the foreign worker population. Her 4-year-old son, Railee, tells us how he feels about not seeing Mummy for a month.
teaserVideo.title: One Of Us - S1: 4-year-old son worries about journalist mum working during COVID-19

tvShows.description: As COVID-19 infections rise among foreigner workers in Singapore, what is being done to deal with this crisis?

Be it education or hospitality, migrant housing or food security, what is the new normal we can expect? This programme offers a refreshing look at some of the issues being addressed and the innovative steps being taken.
